snippet: The announcement came after a recent chain of cases in Liberia was snuffed out, ending an epidemic that killed more than 11,300 people, mostly in West Africa.
abstract: World Health Organization announces end to world's deadliest-ever Ebola outbreak; officials express confidence about handling future outbreaks, while stressing need for continued vigilance and more international investment in preventing recurrence of disease which killed over 11,300 people in West Africa;

byline.original: By DIONNE SEARCEY, NICK CUMMING-BRUCE and CLAIR MacDOUGALL
byline.contributor: Dionne Searcey reported from Dakar, Nick Cumming-Bruce from Geneva and Clair MacDougall from Monrovia, Liberia. Somini Sengupta contributed reporting from the United Nations, and Sheri Fink from New York.

lead_paragraph: The announcement came after a recent chain of cases in Liberia was snuffed out, ending an epidemic that killed more than 11,300 people, mostly in West Africa.

headline.main: Deadliest Ebola Outbreak on Record Is Over, W.H.O. Says
headline.print_headline: Worst Ebola Outbreak Is Over After Two Years, W.H.O. Says
